description.narrative: The Food, Environment, Land and Development Programme and Action Tracker (hereinafter: simply FELD, or Action Tracker) is designed to support countries devise, implement and share experience of effective policies for making their food and land-use systems sustainable. It will do so by tracking national policies and other action at country level, and by assessing the extent to which they advance national and internationally agreed targets, including the Sustainable Development Goals and objectives under the Paris Agreement. Starting in 8-12 countries, the FELD Programme will build on existing FOLU resources and country networks of the FABLE Consortium, in partnership with key intergovernmental organisations. Its integrated analyses will focus on practical relevance for policy makers, and be available to all governments interested in strengthening policies to transform food and land use systems, and their implementation.

The overarching purpose of the FELD Action Tracker is to support the effective transformation of food and land use systems, and substantially add to our understanding of • how national and global commitments are being operationalised in countries, • what policies are proving to be effective in different contexts, and • how we can most effectively facilitate and leverage cross-country learning and sharing on the basis of emerging good practices as part of a comprehensive package of policies. In its design and approach to develop the Action Tracker methodology, SDSN will go beyond checklists of ‘what’ is needed but aim at providing analysis and practical guidance on ‘how’ meaningful change for food and land use systems can be operationalised. By doing so, the FELD Action Tracker will also provide inputs to a range of related initiatives, including the Policy Action Coalition on repurposing agri-food support, and other policy dialogues with and across governments.

recipient-country.narrative: As one of 10 starting countries the FELD Action Tracker will focus on. During the scoping phase covered under this grant though, the work remains at global level.
